repnme.cdata!: Benin - Transport Sector Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcomes are rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact high. Lessons convey that the strong
            persistence, and follow-up during supervision, were the main
            factors conducive to the progress achieved in privatization
            (difficult to attain in light of strong vested interests),
            and improved port management. However, there were problems
            encountered in training small roads contractors,
            particularly due to the lack of expertise in the subject, an
            issue that needs to be dealt with as of the early stages.
            Similarly, it was difficult to mobilize local counterpart
            funding for rural road rehabilitation in the poorest areas;
            it was at the mid-term review that it was decided to take
            only the local labor contribution into account, increase the
            contribution from the national budget - so as to prod
            poverty alleviation - considering in turn, lower road
            standards. Nonetheless, it is important to promote, and
            develop road maintenance systems, a multifaceted effort,
            which involves training of private contractors, and ensuring
            access to capital, and the necessary equipment. This effort
            was successfully achieved, demonstrating how small
            contractors can evolve in urban areas, and how private
            contracting can be promoted for maintaining trunk, and rural
            roads. Most importantly, the independent road fund
            demonstrated once again its valuable experience.

5077260.trustfund:
TF023037-PHRD-TRANSPORT SECTOR PROJECT,TF036251-BENIN - PRIORITY REFORMS TO THE
            TSIP PHASE II,TF034818-BENIN - TRANSPORT SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM
5077260.majtheme: Trade and integration,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Urban development

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Transport Sector Investment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The strategy objectives of the Transport
            Sector Investment Program Project relate directly to country
            issues of competitiveness, administrative capacity, resource
            mobilization and private sector participation.  They are: a)
            to safeguard the competitiveness of Benin's transport
            sector and of its transit corridor through open modal
            competition; b) to improve Government's capacity for
            planning, programming, and managing transport sector
            investments; c) to boost infrastructure maintenance resource
            allocation; d) to boost the recovery of infrastructure user
            charges; e) to expand private sector participation in public
            works and maximize its impact on unskilled labor job
            creation; f) to build capacity in sector institutions and
            optimize human resource utilization; and g) to protect the
            environment and import road safety conditions.  The main
            components are: a) paved road construction, rehabilitation
            and maintenance; b) unpaved road rehabilitation and
            maintenance; c) institutional strengthening for road network
            management; d) feeder roads; e) port and maritime
            improvements; and f) airport rehabilitation.

442738.trustfund:
TF036251-BENIN - PRIORITY REFORMS TO THE
            TSIP PHASE II,TF034818-BENIN - TRANSPORT SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM,TF023037-PHRD-TRANSPORT SECTOR PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Sector Investment Program
            Project  will rehabilitate Benin's main road network
            and set the basis for long term maintenance.  In rural
            areas, the main environmental impacts and accompanying
            mitigation measures will be:  a) laterite quarries, restored
            by leveling the grounds, spreading back organic soil and
            restoring vegetative cover or transformed into water
            reservoirs;  b) wetland degradation, impacted by imbalance
            to fragile ecosystems, loss of agricultural land use, and
            water body eutrophication, mitigated by improved drainage
            infrastructure resulting in the restoration of the original
            water transfers;  c) road drainage leading to accelerated
            formation of gullies and erosion will not have a great
            impact, but can be mitigated by improving downstream road
            drainage systems;  d) atmospheric pollution is negligible
            compared to other sources of air pollution, dust will be
            controlled by frequent watering of construction sites; and
            e) destruction of human habitat, mitigated by compensation
            measures.  There will be no population displacement due to
            the project.  Urban environmental impacts are similar with
            the addition of the risk of flooding which will be helped by
            improved water drainage situation in urban areas.
